thread.title: Harper’s offer to share TPP details with rivals a ‘political ploy,’ Liberals say
thread.title_full: Harper’s offer to share TPP details with rivals a ‘political ploy,’ Liberals say | Toronto Star

author: Tonda MacCharles
title: Harper’s offer to share TPP details with rivals a ‘political ploy,’ Liberals say
text:
TROIS-RIVIÈRES—Conservative Leader Stephen Harper reached out belatedly in the final days of the election campaign to his political rivals, offering private government briefings on the controversial Asia-Pacific trade deal.
But in a sign of the bitterness that now hangs over the country’s longest electoral contest, the Liberals and the New Democrats spurned the offer, calling it too little, too late.
Harper made the offer through his department, the Privy Council Office, just before 1 p.m. Thursday, inviting just two representatives from each party to meet with the government’s chief negotiator for a “detailed, chapter-by-chapter technical briefing” of a text that Harper says has not yet been finalized.
The Liberals called it a “political ploy,” saying they were asked to sign a confidentiality agreement that “does not meet the Liberal Party of Canada’s high standard for transparency.”
In a letter to Harper, NDP leader Tom Quote: : “I can’t agree to a private briefing that leaves Canadians in the dark. This secret trade deal will affect all Canadians. It puts their jobs, their environment and their household budgets at risk.”
Asked why it came now, Conservative spokesman Kory Teneycke said “because we’re nice guys, that’s why.”
Harper acknowledged Thursday the final text would not be available before the election, but said “virtually all” sectors of Canadian industries that could be affected have been briefed and support the deal as good for the Canadian economy. The government has offered $4.3 billion over 15 years to ease dairy, poultry and egg farmers concerns, and $1 billion over 10 years to the auto industry to transition to more foreign competition.
All three national party leaders campaigned hard Thursday in Quebec where they each lay claim to best represent “Quebec values” but slung accusations at each other.
Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau said Harper should be “embarrassed” to associate his campaign with Rob Ford, the self-admitted crack-smoking former Toronto mayor. Harper downplayed a rally announced by his brother Doug Ford, as an event organized not by the Fords but by the Conservative Party of Canada.
But many see it as a sign of desperation by a sagging Conservative campaign .
And as Harper campaigned, his message to voters also lowered its initial expectations.
Unlike Trudeau, Harper won’t say whether he wants Canadians to give him a majority government.
“I and our party, we never take voters for granted. It’s not the way we do things. It’s a tight election,” he told reporters.
It was not out of modesty, but a tactical tweak which acknowledged a certain reality — though Harper would not articulate it.
Just 10 weeks ago, in the early days of the campaign, Harper had no misgivings about calling for a majority, telling an audience in Belleville, Ont., the choice was clear. “It’s a choice we must get right and that choice has been and remains, a strong, stable national majority government.”
He says Trudeau and Mulcair are real threats, and pose grave risks to Canadian taxpayers’ financial stability. But Harper has adopted a tactically cautious approach to any talk of what Parliament would or should look like.
It sounds less arrogant — a lesson he learned to his chagrin in 2004 when voters rejected his calls for a majority. It wasn’t until 2006 voters handed him the first of two minorities, and only in 2011 did he win a majority of seats.
Now after nearly 10 years in power, Harper refuses to answer questions about any post-Oct. 19 scenarios, including how would he work with other parties, and what coalitions could he form to implement an agenda.
It’s not at all clear to the public what Harper’s thinking is about his future, or with which party he believes that a minority Conservative government could seek support even on an issue-by-issue basis. The others — NDP, Liberals, Greens, and Bloc Québécois — have all said they would work to defeat his government.
The Conservative party promised a niqab ban at citizenship ceremonies would be its first legislative act. The Bloc supports that Conservative proposal. But Harper made co-operation with the separatist BQ politically toxic in the 2008 prorogation crisis, damning them as a nationally divisive partner in any coalition.
Conservative strategists and insiders, speaking on background, are frank: a majority is not in the cards if it ever was.
But now there are two distinct camps on whether a minority is even within reach.
Some are downright gloomy, saying the party is losing big. Others are stoic, mindful the party’s big voter identification and get-out-the-vote machine has pulled out wins in the end — like in 2011 when naysayers were surprised.
Harper says only that whoever wins the most seats will govern the country.
Of his own future, he says little. Just that he’s got the best job in the country and would like to continue doing it.
At the outset of the campaign, sources told the Star Harper appeared set to hang on to lead the Conservatives even if one of his rivals won a tenuous minority, believing it would be unstable and short-lived, and that he would be best-placed to lead the Conservatives back to power.
Harper has seemed zen on the campaign trail this week, even energized at a few evening rallies that have drawn larger crowds, but his touring campaign exudes an air of fatigue. Staff are tired, sick and flagging. Harper seems more at ease than those around him.
He told CBC in September that if he doesn’t win the most seats “I would not serve as prime minister.”
To some it suggested Harper would quit but in fact it just states the obvious.
With files from Joanna Smith and Les Whittington
